_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Schreiber Foods, Inc. (SFI) - Headquartered in Green Bay, Wisconsin, Schreiber Foods is the

largest employee-owned dairy company in the world. Schreiber sells its products - which include

cream cheese, natural cheese, process cheese and yogurt - to leading retailers, restaurants,

distributors and food manufacturers around the world. Schreiber has more than 30 manufacturing

and distribution facilities globally in the United States, Austria, Brazil, Bulgaria, Czech Republic,

France, Germany, India, Mexico, Portugal and Spain.



The SFI - Clinton Plant employs approximately 227 people. The SFI plant uses anhydrous

ammonia for refrigeration of the products in storage as well as for cooling of manufacturing process

lines. Anhydrous ammonia is subject to EPA regulation under 40 CFR 68, Accidental Release Risk

Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.



Pursuant to the RMP regulations (40 CFR 68) and the Process Safety Management (PSM)

regulations, SFI has developed a comprehensive PSM written program to protect our employees

and the surrounding community from exposure to the hazardous chemicals onsite. The facility

completed an initial process hazards analyses (PHAs) for ammonia using the industry standard

What-If?/Checklist Analysis developed through the International Institute for Ammonia Refrigeration.

The most recent PHA revalidations were completed in 2017 using the HAZOP methodology which includes all situations evaluated in the

IIAR's What-If?/Checklist Analysis. The original and revalidation PHAs were completed using

technical and operations staff from the Clinton Plant as well as experienced facilitators. The

PHAs reviewed operational, human factors, and facility siting issues relative to the design of the

refrigeration system, and recommendations were made, as appropriate, to address these concerns.



SFI's implementation of the PSM program includes employee education in the hazards of ammonia

and measures that can be used to reduce employee

and community exposure to accidental releases

of ammonia. The plans include preventive maintenance programs (mechanical integrity) for the

ammonia system, and a program for both pre-startup safety reviews and management of changes

(MOC) to the system. The program also includes specific requirements for safe work practices (such

as safe approaches to welding and similar hot work) and safety requirements for contractors who

may be hired to work on the system. Finally, SFI has undertaken a rigorous approach to PSM

compliance auditing. Findings from the audits are reported to the facility, which then must correct

the findings and provide written documentation of resolution of the findings to SFI's Director Safety.



Lastly, the PSM written program incorporates the Plant's emergency response plan and places

special emphasis on handling accidental releases of hazardous chemicals and coordination of

emergency response with local fire departments and other emergency response organizations.

Many of SFI's refrigeration and maintenance personnel have completed 24-hour HAZWOPER

HAZMAT technician level training program. This training includes topics such as classification

systems and hazards identification; ammonia spill control and containment; respiratory protection; air

monitoring instrumentation; proper personal protective equipment; medical monitoring; and proper

termination procedures for emergency response activities. The facility conducts annual

HAZWOPER refresher training to keep employees current and comfortable with their responsibilities

under the plan using classroom discussion and response to mock emergency scenarios. The facility

also conducts quarterly drills during which the emergency response team practices implementation

of the incident command system to respond to mock emergency situations.



As part of the RMP requirements, SFI undertook a review of the potential offsite consequences of

the accidental release of the largest vessel in th

e systems. Although such a release is highly

unlikely, the regulation requires this review.



SFI stores and uses anhydrous ammonia on site for refrigeration of products in storage as well as for

cooling of manufacturing process lines. Ammonia is used for its excellent energy efficiency and

flexibility, in addition to benefits to employee safety. Ammonia at the facility is kept entirely within the

refrigeration system, much as the refrigerant in your car air-conditioner. The SFI - Clinton Plant has 

never experienced a release of ammonia involving consequences that affected residents

or the environment.



SFI is committed to minimizing accidental releases of ammonia from the refrigeration process at the

Clinton Plant. Facility management is involved in the design, operation, and maintenance of

the system. SFI employees at all levels have been involved in the development of the PSM and

RMP programs. Management has committed to working with local agencies and the community to

educate the public regarding the hazards of ammonia and to ensure a safe workplace and surrounding community.
